tasks: Review the 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design (nngroup.com) and identify 3 heuristics that you're not familiar with. Write a brief explanation of each heuristic, including its purpose and any potential pitfalls. Score: 0/100 (0%)
Create a simple wireframe of a login form using the 8-point grid system, focusing on proper alignment and spacing. Reference your portfolio's navigation for inspiration. Score: 1/100 (1%)
Apply Occam's Razor to a current design project or idea. Explain how the principle of simplicity can improve user experience. Score: 0/100 (0%)

Conduct a self-assessment using Miller’s Law, identifying areas where you might be over-designing or adding unnecessary complexity. Write down specific examples and suggestions for improvement. Score: 1/100 (1%)
Create a user persona using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework, focusing on understanding your target audience's goals and pain points. Document 5 key insights about your persona. Score: 0/100 (0%)
Redesign a simple UI element (e.g., a button or form field) using Aesthetic-Usability Effect principles. Test the redesign with 2 users to gather feedback. Score: 1/100 (1%)
Develop a basic user research plan, including methods for data collection and analysis. Apply your new skills to a real-world project or idea. Score: 0/100 (0%)

Create a comprehensive design system document, outlining the principles and guidelines for UI consistency across multiple products or features. Share with your team or mentor for feedback. Score: 1/100 (1%)

resources.readup: As an Explorer UX designer, you have the unique opportunity to shape the user experience of innovative products and services. By combining your curiosity with a passion for design, research, and collaboration, you can uncover new insights and create solutions that delight users and drive business success.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Understanding Hick’s Law and its Application in UX Design
topics.summary: Applying Hick's Law to optimize interactive elements for faster user experience.
practice_points: Create a list of 10 common interactive elements (e.g., dropdown menus, buttons) and estimate the time it takes users to complete each task. Then, apply Hick’s Law to suggest optimal sizes for these elements
Design an A/B test to compare the effectiveness of different button sizes on user completion rates

topics.name: Developing a Style Guide with Aesthetic-Usability Effect in Mind
topics.summary: Creating a style guide that incorporates the aesthetic-usability effect to improve user engagement and experience.
practice_points: Create a mood board with 5 color palettes inspired by nature, and document how each palette affects user behavior according to Aesthetic-Usability Effect

topics.name: Conducting User Interviews using the Jobs-to-be-Done Framework
topics.summary: Gathering insights from users about their motivations and behaviors to inform design decisions.
practice_points: Conduct 3 user interviews using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework, documenting the user's goals, motivations, and pain points

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need for improvement in understanding user needs and behaviors.
insights.detailed: The low score suggests that the designer may not fully comprehend the user's thought process, leading to suboptimal design decisions. This could result in a product that is not user-centered, causing friction and dissatisfaction among users. The designer should strive to understand the user's perspective, empathize with their needs, and validate assumptions through research.
actionable: Conduct user interviews or surveys to gain a deeper understanding of user behaviors and pain points
Analyze existing data on user interactions and feedback to identify areas for improvement
Take online courses or attend workshops to enhance UX fundamentals knowledge

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need for improvement in visual design skills.
insights.detailed: The low score suggests that the designer may not have developed strong visual design skills, resulting in a product with an unappealing or inconsistent aesthetic. This could lead to user disengagement and decreased trust in the product. The designer should focus on developing their visual design skills through practice, experimentation, and feedback.
actionable: Create a portfolio showcasing personal design work to demonstrate skills and style
Join online communities or forums to stay updated with the latest design trends and best practices
Participate in design challenges or hackathons to test and refine visual design skills

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need for improvement in research methods.
insights.detailed: The low score suggests that the designer may not be using effective research methods to validate assumptions or gather user feedback. This could lead to design decisions being made without sufficient evidence, resulting in a product that does not meet user needs. The designer should focus on developing their research skills through training, mentorship, and hands-on experience.
actionable: Enroll in online courses or certification programs focused on user research methods
Collaborate with experienced researchers or mentors to gain insight into best practices
Conduct usability testing or A/B testing to validate design assumptions

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need for improvement in product thinking and strategy.
insights.detailed: The low score suggests that the designer may not be considering the broader product landscape or user needs beyond their immediate design scope. This could lead to a product that is not aligned with business goals or user expectations. The designer should focus on developing their product thinking skills through strategic planning, market research, and collaboration with cross-functional teams.
actionable: Attend product management or strategy courses to develop an understanding of the product's place in the market
Participate in brainstorming sessions or workshops to generate ideas for new features or products

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need for improvement in collaboration and communication skills.
insights.detailed: The low score suggests that the designer may not be effectively communicating design decisions or collaborating with stakeholders to ensure a cohesive product vision. This could lead to misunderstandings, misaligned expectations, or delayed project timelines. The designer should focus on developing their collaboration and communication skills through practice, feedback, and training.
actionable: Join online communities or forums focused on UX design and collaboration
Participate in team-building activities or workshops to improve interpersonal skills
